review.title: Belief revision in the propositional closure of a qualitative algebra (extended version)
review.abstract: Belief revision is an operation that aims at modifying old beliefs so that they become consistent with new ones. The issue of belief revision has been studied in various formalisms, in particular, in qualitative algebras (QAs) in which the result is a disjunction of belief bases that is not necessarily representable in a QA. This motivates the study of belief revision in formalisms extending QAs, namely, their propositional closures: in such a closure, the result of belief revision belongs to the formalism. Moreover, this makes it possible to define a contraction operator thanks to the Harper identity. Belief revision in the propositional closure of QAs is studied, an algorithm for a family of revision operators is designed, and an open-source implementation is made freely available on the web. (This is the extended version of an article originally presented at the 14th International Conference on Principles of Knowledge Representation and Reasoning.)

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: Qualitative revision is an operation of faith modification, which consists in modifying minimally old beliefs so that they are in conformity with new beliefs (Alchourrón et al., 1985). One way to examine this problem from the point of view of presenting knowledge is to consider a formalism and to study some of them defined faith revision operators: how they are defined and how they can be implemented. In particular, it is quite easy to define a revision operator on the basis of a qualitative algebra (such as the Allen algebra) by reusing the work of Condotta et al. (2010) on the related problem of faith fusion. The result of such a faith revision is a set of faith foundations that must be interpreted disjunctively and that are not necessarily depicted as the only basis of faith: qualitative algebras are not closed under disjunction. This technical report represents an extended version of a qualitative revision of a duality algorithm (This is the first part of a qualitative analysis of a duussal).
